title: 114_s2392
content: The Act titled "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause starting in 2017. Cause for removal includes medical negligence or violation of legal or contractual requirements. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" restricts MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause starting in 2017. Causes for removal include medical negligence, violation of legal or contractual requirements, or being unfit to provide services according to the law. Cost to MA organizations is also considered when evaluating a provider's participation in an MA plan network. Starting in 2017, the "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" prohibits MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause. Cost to MA organizations is not a valid reason for mid-year removal, and providers can only be removed for specified reasons before the annual coordinated election period. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" prohibits MA organizations from removing providers without cause. A fair notice and appeal process must be completed before any removal from an MA plan network. The fair notice and appeal process must be followed for the removal of a provider from a Medicare Advantage plan network. This process applies to removals occurring after the effective date specified in the final rule. The termination or suspension of a provider contract under section 422.202(a) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations, shall apply for the removal of a provider from a Medicare Advantage plan network. Written notification must be provided to participants at least 60 days before the provider is removed from the network. The removal of a provider from a Medicare Advantage plan network requires written notification to participants at least 60 days in advance. The notification must include information on alternative in-network providers and options for continuing medical treatment with the removed provider. The Medicare Advantage plan must provide written notification at least 60 days in advance of removing a provider from the network. The notification should include details on alternative in-network providers, options for continuing treatment with the removed provider, and customer service numbers for information on network changes. Additionally, the notification must be included in the annual notice of change for the upcoming plan year. The Medicare Advantage plan must ensure continuity of care for individuals if a provider is removed from the network. Providers have the right to decline participation in the network. MA organizations must be transparent in how they establish or modify provider networks. Beginning in 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering plans must disclose on their website and in bid information the measures used to establish or modify provider networks, including quality and efficiency metrics. The MA organization must disclose measures used to establish or modify provider networks, including quality and efficiency metrics, without including individually identifiable information of providers or suppliers. Enforcement includes sanctions for noncompliance. The Social Security Act is amended to include new subparagraphs related to compliance with specific sections. Sanctions are not applicable to Part D. The Medicare Advantage Plan Compare Tool must be implemented within a year of the Act's enactment. The Social Security Act is amended to include new subparagraphs related to compliance with specific sections, with sanctions not applicable to Part D. The Medicare Advantage Plan Compare Tool must consider the preferences and utilization needs of individuals within a year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. NETWORK ADEQUACY. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, types of services, provider availability, and location when establishing a plan network. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, types of services, provider availability, and location when establishing a plan network. The network access adequacy standards require providers to offer timely services, with input from patient advocacy groups, suppliers, and MA plans. Each year, certification is required for compliance. Each plan year, Medicare Advantage organizations must certify that their network providers can offer required services and meet enrollees' needs. Additionally, they are required to report average wait times for primary and specialty care. The Medicare Advantage organization must report average wait times, utilization of out-of-network providers, and average cost per patient for each plan. They must also certify the accuracy of provider directories and undergo network reviews. The Secretary ensures network adequacy guidelines are met for each Medicare Advantage plan offered by an organization every 3 years or when a material change occurs. Enforcement includes amending relevant sections of the Social Security Act.
